description: {"blocks":[{"key":"50cq3","text":"The Registry of Scientific Collections (ReSciColl) is a metadata catalog administered by the National Geological and Geophysical Data Preservation Program (NGGDPP), It includes essential metadata describing scientific collections, to promote discovery and encourage further exploration of similar items by identifying contacts, providing access instructions, and linking to online resources for additional information.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"chfb3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"drmbq","text":"This document describes the process by which collection metadata is to be submitted to ReSciColl, including metadata for items within a collection. It introduces mdEditor, an open-source, browser-based application for creating metadata records that is highly customizable and uses a graphical user interface developed by the Alaska Data Integration Working Group (ADIwg), a collaboration between the US Geological Survey and the US Fish and Wildlife Service. Many of the mdEditor screenshots used to illustrate this document are from the ADIwg mdEditor online tutorial and reference manual, available at https://guide.mdeditor.org/. This tutorial and reference manual are extremely valuable resources for navigating the tabs, screens, and sections of mdEditor, and the NGGDPP highly recommends ReSciColl users familiarize themselves with these resources.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":604,"length":28}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"7D045B198ED711EE98360A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://guide.mdeditor.org/."}}}}

materials_text: {"blocks":[{"key":"427a3","text":"Introduction to mdEditor","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a3qfv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f3fkr","text":"mdEditor (https://go.mdeditor.org/) is a web application that allows a great deal of flexibility in creation of metadata records for various purposes. The NGGDPP has supported many recent developments in mdEditor to meet the needs of ReSciColl. Further information about mdEditor, including a detailed tutorial and user manual, along with information on other related and connected tools, can be found at https://www.mdtoolkit.org/.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":10,"length":24},{"key":1,"offset":405,"length":26}],"data":{}},{"key":"4f300","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ahhai","text":"Important: Even though mdEditor is accessed via web browser, it keeps all settings, records, and other information locally, in the browser cache, until either exported or published (both are available functions in the application). A best practice is to export (save) records regularly, so that local copies are available and can be imported again for additional editing, publication, or updates, in case the browser cache is cleared for some other purpose. Multiple users can edit a copy of the same record by exporting and importing the content, since there is no way to access an unpublished record except through mdEditor via the web.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4l3f1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9299o","text":"Exporting and importing will be covered in a later section, and additional information can be found in the tutorial and reference manual at https://www.mdtoolkit.org/.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":140,"length":26}],"data":{}},{"key":"611un","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"63du7","text":"If you are using mdEditor for the first time, you may be presented with the warning popup like that shown in Fig. 1. It may also appear after mdEditor has been updated by the developers.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ick8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"mmevj","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2roi0","text":"Click “OK” to continue. A clean instance of the mdEditor dashboard is shown in Fig. 2. mdEditor will show up blank when you first open or after a cache clear as it does not connect to existing ReSciColl collections or content. Fig. 3 depicts an instance of mdEditor with several records of each type. The left side of the mdEditor window lists metadata records, contacts, and dictionaries currently available. Each section can be expanded/collapsed via the carat icon (^) to the left of the section title in its title bar. The main part of the dashboard also shows the three record types with a count of records available by type, 1) metadata, 2) contacts, and 3) dictionaries.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2vo23","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"voan3","text":" steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"5i10u","text":"In mdEditor, Contacts are created and maintained as separate records from metadata records. This enables a contact to be used many times in a single metadata record or across multiple metadata records without requiring a user to reenter the contact's information. Rather than entering a contact's information within a metadata record, mdEditor provides users with a drop-down list of contacts that can be linked to various roles within the metadata record. The available list consists of those contact records currently in the user’s browser instance of mdEditor, typically entered or imported by the user. Like metadata records themselves, contacts can also be imported and exported via JSON format. The NGGDPP is working with ReSciColl users to develop standardized contacts that can be imported and shared among other ReSciColl and mdEditor users within the same organization.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"atr61","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c3n17","text":"See the video below for a walk through the mdEditor Import function:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9lls","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f4tro","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e7kqs","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9mk76","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d0hpr","text":"To import Contacts, select the “Import” option on the top menu bar in mdEditor. The import selection screen will appear (Fig. 4).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2c25k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ofq2a","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"embed","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"code":"\u003ciframe src=\"https://d9-wret.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/assets/palladium/production/s3fs-public/media/video/NGGDPP_ReSciColl_mdEditor_Import.mp4\" height=\"405\" width=\"720\"\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e"}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"height":314,"id":435870,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"fltr9\",\"text\":\"Figure 4: mdEditor Import Data screen with callout boxes highlighting features.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxacaja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjw8caja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjw9caja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjw7caja7.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9c2vr","text":"If the file you wish to import is local (on the user's PC or connected storage), click the large blue box. If it is at a remote web address, enter the address in the “Import from Online URL” box. mdEditor supports three file formats for import: mdEditor (.json), mdJSON (.json), and FGDC CSDGM (.xml). Contacts will generally be shared via the mdEditor JSON format, which can also hold metadata records in the same file. Once the file is selected, the Import Data selection list screen will appear (Fig. 5).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1tfbb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"0jgm5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"br01d","text":"In the example in Fig. 5, Contacts are included below a set of Metadata Records. The Contacts available for import are shown in Fig. 6.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e1ehp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"jndgi","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"803jt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"height":282,"id":435874,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"bd9j2\",\"text\":\"Figure 5: mdEditor Import Data Records/Contacts selection list.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxecaja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxccaja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxdcaja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxbcaja7.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"height":340,"id":435878,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"e3ji7\",\"text\":\"Figure 6: mdEditor Import Data list, showing Contacts available for import.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxicaja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxgcaja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxhcaja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxfcaja7.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9b5pv","text":"All records and contacts are selected by default. Deselect any you do not wish to import, select “Merge” on the “Import/Merge” toggle on the upper right (Fig. 5), and select the “Click to Import Data” button. Fig. 7 shows a previously clean instance of mdEditor with all the example records and contacts from Figs. 5 and 6 imported (in the lists on the left side of the screen).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2rdnm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"etnk3","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"height":269,"id":435882,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"do5rh\",\"text\":\"Figure 7: mdEditor Dashboard after importing 9 Metadata Records and 9 Contacts.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxncaja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxkcaja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxmcaja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxjcaja7.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"19ksk","text":"If you need to create a new contact record in mdEditor, click the plus sign (+) to the right of the “Contacts” section header on the left side (see the “Create New Contact” callout in Fig. 9). As shown in Fig. 8, you can choose whether to create a contact for an individual (e.g., Jane Doe, Richard Roe) or an organization (e.g., U.S. Geological Survey, U.S. Department of Interior). Clicking the switch icon between the labels for Individual and Organization will toggle the type of contact to be created. The field labeled “Contact ID” is a system generated Universally Unique Identifier (UUID) for the contact. It is used by mdEditor to link the contact to other contacts and/or metadata records. If your organization uses a different identification code system for identifying contacts, you will need to change the value here from the generated UUID to your organization’s ID at this point, before proceeding. Enter either the individual’s name or the organization’s name in the “Name” field as appropriate, and, if creating an individual contact, a “Position Name” is also required. Required fields in mdEditor are always indicated by a red asterisk (*) after the field name.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"co5dd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"om5ev","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"height":252,"id":435886,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"17mgh\",\"text\":\"Figure 8: Create New Contact dialog.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxscaja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxqcaja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxrcaja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxpcaja7.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"933rh","text":"Click “Save,” and the full contact edit window will be presented (Fig. 9).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6tmmu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fqvuf","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6ftua","text":"In the contact editing window, you can add all relevant metadata for the contact, including phone numbers, email addresses, etc. You can also link an individual or organization to another organization via the “Member of Organization” drop-down list, presuming the contact for the desired organization has already been created or imported.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9em25","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"atc8d","text":"If your organization has more than one user creating and/or maintaining metadata records for ReSciColl, you may wish to share contact records in order to maintain consistency. If one user created an individual contact for “John Smith,” and another user in the organization also created a contact for “John Smith,” and yet another created “John A. Smith,” yet all three refer to the same person, when editing and publishing records that link to those separate contacts, they would be considered as three different individuals, as each would have a unique UUID/Contact ID. Exporting contacts from mdEditor allows sharing contact records, in order to minimize the likelihood of the above scenario. Exporting contacts will be covered in a later section, along with general exporting from mdEditor. When creating or editing contacts, including persistent identifiers such as ORCiDs and/or RORs is highly encouraged as this practice increases the accuracy and quality of the metadata.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ejspr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ebml","text":"Additional information on Contacts in mdEditor can be found in the online tutorial and reference manual:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dq0ls","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1oi69","text":"https://guide.mdeditor.org/reference/edit-window/contact/contact-record.html","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":76}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"height":502,"id":435890,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"9aoiu\",\"text\":\"Figure 9: Editing Contact window, with callout boxes highlighting features.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxwcaja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxucaja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxvcaja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxtcaja7.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"674B0AE38EDA11EE98360A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://guide.mdeditor.org/reference/edit-window/contact/contact-record.html"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fdlpc","text":"mdEditor is designed with the use of what are referred to as profiles to customize the visibility of metadata elements when creating a metadata record. They may also be considered views, as all metadata elements remain available, but a particular profile, when loaded, may not display every possible field for entry. They may also be used for custom enforcement of required content, depending on the type of resource being described by the metadata record. Profiles can only be switched while in edit mode.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ebmpm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8gacs","text":"For ReSciColl, we have provided an initial set of five domain profiles that are currently loaded along with the defaults:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ctk2d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6uccb","text":"1. NGGDPP Common: A core profile which ensures all metadata elements required by the NGGDPP are collected. All elements visible in this profile are also visible in the following four domain-specific profiles.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8lerp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9fuf8","text":"2. NGGDPP Geological: A profile designed for collections of geological samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fh8db","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ade9a","text":"3. NGGDPP Image: A profile designed for collections of images/photographs.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1t10s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"at68s","text":"4. NGGDPP Invertebrate: A profile designed for collections of biological samples of invertebrate species.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bbpt0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9kbaq","text":"5. NGGDPP Vertebrate: A profile designed for collections of biological samples of vertebrate species.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9k2fm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e0krf","text":"The NGGDPP continues to develop additional profiles for other collection types, and suggestions are always welcome.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3epr7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ce3r4","text":"Before continuing with creating a record, select the profile appropriate for the type of collection being described. Changing the current profile can be done in the top menu bar, in black, via the drop-down menu labeled “Profile” (Fig. 10).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ol1s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"uy1dm","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"t4fu","text":"This will change what metadata elements, sections, and menus are shown, as well as, in the case of the NGGDPP domain profiles, what keyword lists are available. Profiles can always be switched during editing, as the entire metadata schema (all defined fields/elements) is always available. Each of the NGGDPP domain profiles (Geological, Image, Invertebrate, Vertebrate) displays all the fields
and keyword lists available in the NGGDPP Common profile, along with specific fields and keyword lists deemed relevant to those domains.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":161,"length":128}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"etjc5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"17dhb","text":"Once you have selected a profile, you are ready to enter the metadata for the collection into the record. The basics of navigating the mdEditor interface are covered in an online tutorial that is available here:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2dpq9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6i5k1","text":"mdEditor Tutorial (https://guide.mdeditor.org/tutorial/welcome-to-tutorial.html)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":80}],"data":{}},{"key":"f8k70","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5bkfo","text":"In order to maximize the Findability, Accessibility, Interoperability, and Reusability (the FAIR Principles) of ReSciColl collections, the NGGDPP recommended best practice is to complete as much of the available metadata as possible. When creating a collection record in mdEditor, visit each of the
available tabs for the selected profile, and provide as much information as is available for each field, whether or not a field is required. Also, if you have metadata information for an element that is not visible when using a specific profile, switching to another profile is possible, even during editing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9polk","text":"mdEditor also comes with four default profiles:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9o3hj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3q29c","text":"    Full (every available metadata element in the mdJSON schema)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8go5e","text":"    Basic (minimal subset of metadata elements)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"arj1s","text":"    Product (subset of metadata elements commonly used for product metadata, e.g., data releases)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1go0n","text":"    Project (subset of metadata elements commonly used for project metadata, e.g., field
campaigns)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"54r4h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9291u","text":"These profiles are also always available.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"298rb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"height":197,"id":435894,"is_video":false,"legend":"{"blocks":[{"key":"evhs","text":"Figure 10: mdEditor profiles drop-down menu, featuring NGGDPP domain profiles.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjx2caja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxycaja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxzcaja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjxxcaja7.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"C5F81BDB9F4711EE886F0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://guide.mdeditor.org/tutorial/welcome-to-tutorial.html"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7pl3a","text":"ReSciColl users who have collection metadata, as well as metadata for items within a collection, must create the collection metadata record before uploading metadata for that collection’s items. To add a collection in ReSciColl, visit the ReSciColl website:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5oo8p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3r831","text":"https://webapps.usgs.gov/rescicoll/index.html","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":45}],"data":{}},{"key":"oeg7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c7ojv","text":"In the “Collections Management” section on the lower right side of the page, click on the “Create New Collection – mdEditor” button (highlighted by the yellow ellipse in Fig. 11):","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cc3va","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cnttc","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2qr5i","text":"Your browser will be redirected to the website for mdEditor (https://go.mdeditor.org/), ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":61,"length":24}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"3BF96A3D9F4811EE886F0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://webapps.usgs.gov/rescicoll/index.html"}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":363,"id":435898,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"cvcv7\",\"text\":\"Figure 11. ReSciColl homepage, https://webapps.usgs.gov/rescicoll/index.html.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[{\"key\":0,\"offset\":31,\"length\":45}],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{\"0\":{\"type\":\"link\",\"mutability\":\"MUTABLE\",\"data\":{\"guid\":\"D8A7037C9F4811EE886F0A58A9FEAC02\",\"url\":\"https://webapps.usgs.gov/rescicoll/index.html\"}}}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"Picture1.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjx6caja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjx4caja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjx5caja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjx3caja7.webp","width":550}},"2":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"E928614E9F4811EE886F0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://go.mdeditor.org"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8icku","text":"On the mdEditor dashboard, in the primary sidebar on the left side, click the plus (+) sign to the right of the count of metadata records to create a new one (Fig. 12).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c19o5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6sdvh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"btmpp","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bak0d","text":"The “Create New Record” screen appears (Fig. 13).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fs6nr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"96mi0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dvqcl","text":"As indicated by the callout boxes in Fig. 13, you will need to provide a title for the record. This is the collection title that will be displayed by ReSciColl. In the Resource Types section, from the Type drop-down list, choose the appropriate type(s). For ReSciColl, there must always be at least one Resource Type with a value of “collection.” In the Name field to the right, you can provide a name for the type of collection to be represented by this record if it is not represented in the list of Resource Types (e.g., field notebooks, hyperspectral image data, thin sections).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":254,"length":92},{"style":"italic","offset":254,"length":92}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"851hh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7lcan","text":"Once you have entered a title and resource type, the “Save” button will become available.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":269,"id":435902,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"bv5q3\",\"text\":\"Figure 12: mdEditor dashboard with callout box highlighting where to add new features.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjyecaja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjyccaja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjydcaja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjybcaja7.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bpevm","text":"After saving the initial information for the record, as shown in Fig. 14, the main Edit Window for mdEditor will appear. The screenshot in Fig. 14 shows the various sections of the mdEditor interface when in edit mode. See the online tutorial and reference manual for more information: https://guide.mdeditor.org/.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":286,"length":28}],"data":{}},{"key":"2qjls","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fgbec","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"afvu8","text":"Before creating a metadata record for a collection with mdEditor, users should ensure they have the appropriate contact records in mdEditor, as discussed in the Contacts section above.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5hvc2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7soca","text":"One of the NGGDPP requirements and best practices for ReSciColl, as well as several metadata standards, is to record the people and/or organizations related both to the resource being described by the metadata record and those involved in creating and maintaining the metadata record itself. If any contacts are missing that are relevant to the record you are creating or editing, they must be added or imported to your mdEditor contacts before they can be associated with a metadata record.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cu5ao","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"82F945439F4A11EE886F0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://guide.mdeditor.org/."}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":387,"id":435910,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"42oq4\",\"text\":\"Figure 14: mdEditor Editing Metadata Record screen, showing Main tab and callout boxes highlighting features. \\\"Breadcrumbs\\\" show the path taken within mdEditor to get to the current screen, and can be used for navigation within the application.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjyicaja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjygcaja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjyhcaja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjyfcaja7.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4818c","text":"Points of Contact","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5imlf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1emd4","text":"On the Main tab in mdEditor, immediately below Resource Type, is a section called “Points of Contact” (Fig. 15). The contacts added in this section on this tab should be people and organizations associated with the specific collection resource being described. At least one contact must be added as Point of Contact with a role of “owner.” Other contacts may be added here with other roles (e.g., principalInvestigator, collaborator), including associated organization contacts. The complete list of available roles, along with short definitions, can be found here: http://mdtools.adiwg.org/#codes-page?c=iso_role","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":261,"length":78},{"style":"italic","offset":261,"length":78}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":566,"length":47}],"data":{}},{"key":"dqefj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"er4ce","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bfpfm","text":"In the drop-down list for Role, select “owner,” and then select from the available contacts via the Contacts drop-down list to the right. Your collection metadata record should have at least one owner, and it can have more than one. To add additional owners, continue to select them from the Contacts drop-down list. You can only have one entry for a particular role, but that role can have multiple contacts associated with it. If you have additional contacts in other roles, you can add them via the “Add” button on the upper right of the Points of Contact section.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8abdp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"E2B7A7DDAF2411EE8CED0A58A9FEAC02","url":"http://mdtools.adiwg.org/#codes-page?c=iso_role"}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":306,"id":435914,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"4oqc4\",\"text\":\"Figure 15: mdEditor Main tab, Resource Types and Points of Contacts sections.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjyncaja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjykcaja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjymcaja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjyjcaja7.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5efvr","text":"Citations","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b2mmk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e6v3b","text":"Citation sections can be found in several locations in mdEditor, because a metadata record can reference many different resources, including associated resources, documents, taxonomic systems, etc. On the Main tab, the citation is for the resource itself (the collection). A blank Citation section is shown in Fig.16. It inherits the Title from the record title, and other information can be added by clicking either the “Edit” or “Edit Citation” button. Doing so will bring up the “Editing Citation” window, which allows completion of several metadata items, including responsible parties, online resources, and identifiers. Adding a persistent identifier such as a DOI, if available, to the citation for the collection is highly encouraged, and increases the quality and findability of the metadata.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":626,"length":175},{"style":"italic","offset":626,"length":175}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2e65k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c7ucp","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"11oi3","text":"To add an identifier, click the “Add Identifier” button, which will open the section shown in Fig. 17.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f61kg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1sf5u","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ft5du","text":"Fig. 17 shows the “Identifier” field in which a DOI has been entered (only the DOI itself is required – the full web address is not required). Selecting “DOI” in the “Namespace” field below the identifier is highly recommended, in part because, once the collection has been published, another identifier will be added to the resource citation via ScienceBase, consisting of the ScienceBase ID for the collection, with an associated namespace of “gov.sciencebase.catalog” (Fig. 18).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"do1o2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6e9jm","text":" {"blocks":[{"key":"5f121","text":"Description","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c5tg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4shpg","text":"Also on the Main tab is a Description section, where a required abstract for the collection must be entered (Fig. 19). mdEditor provides a box that supports Markdown and rich text formatting. As shown in Fig. 19, during editing, it will highlight items to be checked for spelling.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dfrg0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4vk48","text":"Note: There is no “Save” option specifically for the edit window for Abstract (or for many other sections in mdEditor). Once you enter or change text in the window, mdEditor recognizes the record has changed, and you can save it via the main “Save” button for the record, or it will autosave periodically if you have that option turned on in Settings (described in the \"Settings\" section of this protocol, Step 29).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cltki","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"crs5m","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ck8e5","text":"The Description section also provides text entry boxes for “Purpose” (to describe the purpose of the collection) and “Supplemental Information” (any other useful information about the collection that is neither the purpose nor part of the abstract). These are not required but their use is highly encouraged.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bguh2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":238,"id":435930,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"dp4vt\",\"text\":\"Figure 19: mdEditor Description text editor window for Abstract.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjy6caja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjy4caja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjy5caja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjy3caja7.webp","width":550}}}}

While single dates can be entered in many places in mdEditor, this section allows for a range, when both a Start Date and End Date are known.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4p76o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"602pi","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b2ri6","text":"Clicking the calendar icon to the right of each date field will bring up a calendar-based date picker (Fig. 21). {"blocks":[{"key":"9d01p","text":"Basic Information","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ahfp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8ofh2","text":"Select the status of the metadata via the drop-down list and select the “Add Date” button to associate a date with the record (Fig. 22).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ol29","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"89gtp","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bb3o7","text":"You can add a date via the date picker (calendar icon). For “Date Type,” you must have at least one date with a date type of “creation” (Fig. 23). A description to provide further info about the date is optional. If you are updating an existing record, it should already have a date associated with “creation,” and you should therefore add an additional date entry, e.g., “revision,” or another appropriate type from those available in the drop-down list.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":56,"length":79},{"style":"italic","offset":56,"length":79}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f0cq8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"born7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7939a","text":"Note: These dates on the mdEditor Metadata tab are dates that are associated with the metadata record itself, not the resource being described (the collection itself). Dates related to the collection are added on the Main tab, which is described in the Main Tab section above.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5u3rk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":186,"id":435946,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"8s2fp\",\"text\":\"Figure 22: mdEditor Metadata Status section.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjzncaja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjzkcaja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjzmcaja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjzjcaja7.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":118,"id":435942,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"dose7\",\"text\":\"Figure 23: mdEditor Dates dialog.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjzicaja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjzgcaja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjzhcaja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjzfcaja7.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"711im","text":"Metadata Contacts","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c19el","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f9ma","text":"People and organizations associated with creating, updating, and maintaining the metadata associated with the resource should be added to the Metadata Contacts section on the Metadata tab. At least one contact must be added with a role of “author.” To add a metadata contact to a collection metadata record, scroll down until you see the “Add Metadata Contact” button (Fig. 24).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"20kd9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bk1hk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b4odd","text":"In the drop-down list for Role, select “author,” and then select from the available contacts via the Contacts drop-down list to the right. Your collection metadata record should have at least one author, and it can have more than one. To add additional authors, continue to select them from the Contacts drop-down list. You can only have one entry for a particular role, but that role can have multiple contacts associated with it. If you have additional metadata contacts in other roles, you can add them via the “Add” button on the upper right of the Metadata Contacts section (Fig. 25).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9if0a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"agnf5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"97at7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":350,"id":435950,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"1mqeh\",\"text\":\"Figure 24: mdEditor Metadata Contacts section (empty).\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjzscaja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjzqcaja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjzrcaja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjzpcaja7.webp","width":464}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":126,"id":435954,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"lckl\",\"text\":\"Figure 25: mdEditor Metadata Contacts section, Role and Contacts selection example.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjzwcaja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjzucaja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjzvcaja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjztcaja7.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5jfk3","text":"Metadata Identifier","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5nc7h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bue3g","text":"This section of the Metadata tab is where mdEditor stores the UUID it assigns to the metadata record when you create it. It can be edited if your organization uses a different identification system (as with the UUIDs for Contacts described in that section), but only one metadata identifier object is permitted by the schema.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79fsa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5hf6q","text":"A major goal of ReSciColl is to make collections FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable). To facilitate this, the NGGDPP has connected several curated, controlled vocabularies that are available online to the Keywords feature in mdEditor. We strongly encourage users to add as many relevant keywords as possible to their collection records using this feature.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c5htv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3fer3","text":"To access this feature, select the Keywords tab in the mdEditor menu bar. You’ll be presented with the screen shown in Fig. 27. First, add a thesaurus by clicking either of the “+ Add Thesaurus” buttons.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aef8r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"78rlp","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"82np9","text":"What mdEditor defines as a thesaurus is actually a metadata object that may contain a selected keyword list. Several keyword lists are available by default in mdEditor, and others have been made available depending on the NGGDPP domain profile in use.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a7d11","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":137,"id":435962,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"gt8q\",\"text\":\"Figure 27: mdEditor Keywords tab (empty).\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjz6caja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjz4caja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjz5caja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjz3caja7.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1qoao","text":"Once you’ve added a thesaurus, an available keyword list can be selected from the drop-down list (Fig. 28). In the figure, the cursor is pointing at the “?” icon to the right of the “NGGDPP ReSciColl ScienceBase Type Tags” vocabulary/keyword list. When available, these will bring up a pop-up displaying a brief definition of the terms contained in that keyword list. Click on the keyword list name to the left of the “?” to assign a particular keyword list to the thesaurus.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a303k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5gh4e","text":"Note: Only one keyword list can be assigned to a thesaurus object in mdEditor. If you wish to add keywords from more than one list, you will need to add a thesaurus for each list. If you select a particular list in error, you can change it via the drop-down menu up until you have added keywords from the list to the thesaurus. Once keywords have been selected from a list, if you no longer want that list in the metadata record, you will need to delete the thesaurus object.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9v7af","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4psk4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"225pi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":334,"id":435966,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"fdsp1\",\"text\":\"Figure 28: mdEditor keyword list selection drop-down for Thesaurus object example.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","originalFile":{},"original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pj2acaja7.jpg","source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjz8caja7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjz9caja7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/pjz7caja7.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"epk8s","text":"After selecting a keyword list, you can add individual keywords to the metadata record by clicking the “Edit Keywords” button (Fig. 29).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5hpsr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2b6l5","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2sj4g","text":"The “Editing Thesaurus” screen will be presented, with the number of the thesaurus object, along with the name of the keyword list being used (Fig. 30; in this case, the USGS Thesaurus).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5omic","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3jp5r","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e26hp","text":"As with the keyword lists, categories, subcategories, and terms may have definitions available by pointing to the “?” icon to the right of the entry.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bd69n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8eplb","text":"If the keyword list is hierarchical, the categories and subcategories can be expanded using the “+” icons to the left of the category name. If the list is flat, or you have reached the lowest level, no “+” icon is shown (Fig. 31). An expanded section can be collapsed by clicking the “-” icon that appears when expanded. In Fig. 31, the “sciences” category has been expanded, along with the “earth sciences” subcategory, and the “geography” subcategory. The terms “cartography” and “paleogeography” are at the lowest level in this part of the hierarchy, representing individual keywords.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"be5g0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6hhih","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dg8q4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"height":143,"id":435970,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"4p8l9\",\"text\":\"Figure {"blocks":[{"key":"3qhm9","text":"Extents are used in mdEditor to describe the geographic bounds of the resource (temporal extents can be defined via the Time Period object on the Main tab). For ReSciColl collections, at least one geographic extent is required. It can be of any type or feature (e.g., bounding box, polygon, point), and an extent can contain more than one feature. Instructions for creating extents can be found in the mdEditor tutorial linked above. In the ScienceBase Publishing Settings entry in mdEditor, a Default Parent Identifier is required to publish (Fig. 39). This is the ScienceBase item ID for your organization page within the ReSciColl community on ScienceBase.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4cflh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3tq5u","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3dcl4","text":"If there is no Default Parent Identifier present, it will need to be added. If you need to add or change it, you can simply paste it over what, if anything, is there. {"blocks":[{"key":"9r786","text":"mdEditor supports the ability to save the currently loaded Metadata Records, Contacts, and Dictionaries either as an mdEditor file or an mdJSON file. These files can then be shared with collaborators or saved to a local workstation for backup and/or archiving. By default, exported files will be saved in your computer's \"downloads\" folder. This default location can be changed in your browser's settings, generally under the \"Downloads\" section. You can export all records or select from those currently available. You can also include the current set of mdEditor Settings in the exported file(s).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2s3dd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d6mt2","text":"See {"blocks":[{"key":"ahtpf","text":"Now, mdEditor can be used to edit the record as needed. When editing is complete, there are no errors in the record, and it is ready for republication, users should first verify in the mdEditor Settings that the Default Parent ID is set to the correct organization page in ScienceBase, described in the \"Settings\" section of this protocol, Step 29.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"etl49","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3d1f","text":"On the Main tab of the Settings page, under “Publishing Settings,” you will find an entry for “ScienceBase” near the bottom of the screen. A Default Parent Identifier is required to publish (Fig. 60). This is the ScienceBase item ID for your organization page within the ReSciColl community on ScienceBase.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"drlrv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"95i0r","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9r96","text":"If there is no Default Parent Identifier present, it will need to be added. It can be obtained by copying the last part of the web link for your organization’s page on ScienceBase (e.g., the portion at the end of this link in bold text: https://www.sciencebase.gov/catalog/item/6390c2f2d34ed907bf7e380e – highlighted in Fig. 61 by the yellow ellipse).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":278,"length":24}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ep503","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9j99b","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7691b","text":"If you have difficulty locating or otherwise using the ID, please contact the NGGDPP for assistance. {"blocks":[{"key":"83mu8","text":"Once the collection is available on ReSciColl, such as the example shown in Fig. 54, you may add metadata for items within the collection, and you may also add attachments (e.g., images, documents).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cs73j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6murv","text":"The tables in this section list the nineteen (19) metadata elements accepted by ReSciColl. Some metadata elements are mandatory and must be included to adequately describe records. Other metadata elements are optional but recommended, when available, to enhance metadata records for ReSciColl users.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4phu8","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"72tc7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5f0rf","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"39efr","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b4dfr","text":"Map the sample level properties found in your collection to ReSciColl metadata elements by creating a Microsoft Excel or CSV file with column headings that match the metadata elements described in Tables 1 and 2 with rows containing the metadata for each item in the collection. An Excel template is available to download here. In some cases, this might be a one-to-one mapping. For instance, the “date” element might correspond to the 'DateCreated' property in your collection database. For the abstract, it may be desirable to concatenate several fields to provide a richer description of the resource and more specific search results. If the location information is stored in township/range/section, it will be necessary to convert these values to a single geographic latitude and longitude point to populate the required WGS84 coordinates metadata elements. The descriptive township/range/section may then be provided in the alternateGeometry field.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":322,"length":4}],"data":{}},{"key":"c6qjb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"tables","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"cellsMeta":{"0_0":"","0_1":"","0_2":"","1_0":"","1_1":"","1_2":"","2_0":"","2_1":"","2_2":"","3_0":"","3_1":"","3_2":"","4_0":"","4_1":"","4_2":"","5_0":"","5_1":"","5_2":"","6_0":"","6_1":"","6_2":"","7_0":"","7_1":"","7_2":""},"colTitles":["","",""],"colWidths":[118,200,102],"data":[[" Element Name "," Definition ","

If so, this text field should be used to describe the authoritative source for geographic location and how the simple coordinates were derived. Examples of authoritative sources include: Getty place names – Linked open data (LOD) resource, includes API and SPARQL queries (http://vocab.getty.edu/queries); USGS GNIS: U.S. and Territories only, search through U.S. Board on Geographic Names (https://geonames.usgs.gov/apex/f?p=138:1::::::); USGS GAZ – Connected to GNIS, U.S. names (https://edits.nationalmap.gov/apps/gaz-domestic/public); Library of Congress terms – A linked data service (https://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/identifiers/geogndb.html)"," 1 "],[" onlineResource "," URI (Uniform Resource Identifier or web link) of an item-level data source."," ≥1 "],[" browseGraphic "," One or more URI pointers to images representing the specific record."," ≥1 "],[" date "," If a meaningful date within the geosciences domain can be attached to the record (e.g., collection date, map publication date), it can be supplied here. "," ≥1 "],[" verticalExtent "," Vertical extent is useful for describing rock core samples and borehole depths. Examples of authoritative sources include: Getty place names – Linked open data (LOD) resource, includes API and SPARQL queries (http://vocab.getty.edu/queries); USGS GNIS: U.S. and Territories only, search through U.S. Board on Geographic Names (https://geonames.usgs.gov/apex/f?p=138:1::::::); USGS GAZ – Connected to GNIS, U.S. names (https://edits.nationalmap.gov/apps/gaz-domestic/public); Library of Congress terms – A linked data service (https://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/identifiers/geogndb.html)"," 1 "],[" onlineResource "," URI (Uniform Resource Identifier or web link) of an item-level data source."," ≥1 "],[" browseGraphic "," One or more URI pointers to images representing the specific record."," ≥1 "],[" date "," If a meaningful date within the geosciences domain can be attached to the record (e.g., collection date, map publication date), it can be supplied here. Date may be to any degree of precision or may be left blank to indicate uncertainty. Examples: 2001, 2001-2003, 1939-1945, 20030331, 20000331-20000401. "," ≥1 "],[" verticalExtent "," Vertical extent is useful for describing rock core samples and borehole depths. Specification of extent must contain three elements, in the following order, with no spaces between them: unit of measure (meter, feet), maximum depth, minimum depth. Example: m,35.4,0 for a rock core measured at maximum depth of 35.4 meters from the surface."," 1 "],[" IGSN "," International Generic Sample Number (IGSN) of the physical item in the collection (e.g., cutting, core, specimen). Only the IGSN itself is required, not the full web link (e.g., 10273/ICDP5054ESYI201, not http://doi.org/10273/ICDP5054ESYI201)."," 1 "],[" parentIGSN "," The IGSN of the parent material (sample) the derivative material (subsample) was obtained from. Only the IGSN itself is required, not the full web link. "," 1 "],[" relIGSN "," The IGSN of a related sample or subsample (e.g., duplicate, or split). Only the IGSN itself is required, not the full web link."," ≥1 "],[" relationType "," Relationship of the IGSN to the largerWorkCitation. Use the DataCite Relation Type vocabulary terms here: https://www.sciencebase.gov/vocab/vocabulary/611d428bbfff3461918aba6e"," ≥1 "],[" largerWorkCitation "," Physical sample connection to publication (DOI). The collection may document a larger set of samples with only a section used in a journal article. Only the DOI itself is required, not the full web link."," 1 "],[" attachmentFileName "," Full name of file that is to be linked to the item via the file attachment process. A full folder/directory path is not required, just the filename and extension. Must exactly match the name used during file attachment ingest."," 1 "]],"rowHeights":[23,23,23,23,23,23,23,23,23,23,23,23,23]}},"2":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"972864DCA0F111EE945B0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.sciencebase.gov/catalog/item/6377bb81d34ed907bf6f8eaf?name=ReSciColl_Item-Level_Metadata_Template_2023-06-20.xlsx"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5ptuv","text":"ReSciColl Dashboard supports two primary formats for loading data into ReSciColl. Data providers may submit Comma Separated Value (CSV) formatted files or XLSX (Microsoft Excel) files. These formats are discussed in more detail below.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1t5nd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"almg4","text":"File Format","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4dcne","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e1jj4","text":"A CSV file format represents tabular data. Each row in the file corresponds to a single metadata record, and the properties associated with each record are separated by a comma. The comma is a special character that separates data fields, which is useful for recording item/sample characteristics. However, comma delimited files present issues when data fields include commas, which requires enclosing entire fields in double quotes (“) so that the embedded commas are not regarded as field delimiters but as part of the field information. For properties that contain more than one value, the ReSciColl Item Ingest Tool requires data providers to use double quotes around fields that contain values within a single element. For example, a single record with five fields might look like the following, using double quotes as special delimiter characters:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5enr2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6b5l8","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"26ga4","text":"The above line contains five fields, three with multiple values enclosed in double quotes, with the final field containing two dates.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"efjsd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7eu9q","text":"CSV formatted files must also include a header on the first line that indicates the metadata element names and delimiters corresponding to the subsequent data (similar to a map legend). Applying this to the above example, the first two lines of the CSV file would look like the following:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4gss3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9mq8j","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"clfbg","text":"Most databases may output CSV formatted files through built-in utilities, or customized queries. Microsoft Excel may be used to produce CSV formatted files, but the options for character encoding and delimiters are not as flexible as with other CSV file creation tools and must be considered carefully. Excel uses the system settings to determine character encoding and delimiters and will automatically enclose in double quotes any fields containing commas within, and for CSV files, Excel will automatically insert the commas between fields. On a Windows platform, delimiters may be set by accessing the Control Panel --\u003e Regional and Language Options. This option is not available on a Macintosh. Excel file format (*.xlsx) may also be used, but observe caution with date formats, as dates of the text itself, not the field formatting, must follow the structure given in the tables on pp. 1 – 2, e.g., YYYY, YYYYMMDD.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"lmdh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ftf6m","text":"Note: If uploading a file in Excel (*.xlsx) format, make sure all the columns/fields are of either text, general, or number format. Do not use date or other specific formats, as that affects how the data are saved, and could cause validation errors in
